passages.title: Written Composition: Persuasive
passages.content: Think carefully about the following question: Do people have to be competitive in order to succeed? Write an essay stating your position on whether competition is necessary for success.

passages.title: To a Daughter with Artistic Talent
passages.author: Peter Meinke

questions.questionText: J.T. would like to add the following sentence to the first paragraph (sentences 1-6): 'Students from around the world are also part of musical marching groups.' Where is the most effective place to insert this sentence?

options.A: After sentence 1
options.B: After sentence 2
options.C: After sentence 4
options.D: After sentence 5

questions.questionText: J.T. wants to use a more appropriate transition in sentence 11. Which of the following can best replace Furthermore in this sentence?

options.F: For example
options.H: Overall
options.J: Instead

questions.questionText: What is the most effective revision to make in sentence 15?

options.A: A misstep by just one student and a flaw is created that is visible in the perfectly coordinated display.
options.B: A misstep by just one student creates a visible flaw in the perfectly coordinated display.
options.C: A misstep by just one student creates a flaw in the perfectly coordinated display, the flaw is visible.
options.D: A misstep by just one student creates a visible flaw that can be seen in the perfectly coordinated display.

questions.questionText: J.T. has included an extraneous sentence in his paper. Which of these sentences should be deleted from this paper?

options.F: Sentence 9
options.H: Sentence 18
options.J: Sentence 20

questions.questionText: Mimi's essay does not have a strong position statement. Which of the following sentences should replace sentence 6 to serve as an effective position statement?

options.A: It's foolish to buy several bottles of water each day when there's no good reason for doing this.
options.B: People need to stop doing this now and protest against bottled-water companies.
options.C: These problems can be solved, however, if people choose to drink water from reusable containers instead of plastic bottles.
options.D: The list of problems that people are causing, such as increasing pollution, by buying bottled water is endless.

questions.questionText: What is the most effective way to combine sentences 8 and 9?

options.F: Bottled water may be attractively packaged, but it is simply processed tap water.
options.G: Bottled water is simply processed tap water because it is attractively packaged.
options.H: Bottled water may be attractively packaged, so it is simply processed tap water.
options.J: Bottled water is attractively packaged, because it is simply processed tap water.

questions.questionText: Mimi wants to improve the transition between the third paragraph (sentences 14-18) and the fourth paragraph (sentences 19-23). Which sentence can be added before sentence 19 to accomplish this goal?

options.A: Because bottled water can cost so much, a reusable water bottle is a wise investment.
options.B: People think bottled water is harmless, and other plastic containers are just as bad.
options.C: Money is a concern for many people, so it should be saved whenever possible.
options.D: Bottled water is a huge monetary expense, but the cost to our planet is even greater.

questions.questionText: What is the most effective way to revise sentence 21?

options.F: Also consider that many bottles are discarded into landfills, where the bottles release chemicals as they decompose over hundreds of years.
options.G: Also consider that landfills are filled with released chemicals, where they decompose many discarded bottles over hundreds of years.
options.H: These bottles, decomposing over hundreds of years, should also be considered to release chemicals where they have been discarded into landfills.
options.J: Over hundreds of years, landfills are filled with many bottles, and it should also be considered that the bottles decompose and release chemicals.

questions.questionText: Mimi wants to conclude her essay by motivating her readers to take action. Which of the following statements should she insert after sentence 29 to accomplish this goal?

options.A: The future of our planet depends on people like you doing away with a terrible threat-plastic water bottles.
options.B: We should make the decision today to be smart about our finances and responsible with our planet by opting for reusable water bottles.
options.C: Think of how much you can help the fish in our lakes, rivers, and oceans by avoiding bottled water.
options.D: Choose reusable water bottles, and watch your savings grow.

questions.questionText: What change, if any, needs to be made in sentence 2?

options.F: Change being to I am
options.H: Change plays to playing
options.J: Sentence 2 should not be changed.

questions.questionText: What is the correct way to write sentence 5?

options.A: I pull gently at its crisp brown shell, the aroma of its gooey sweetness that teases my nostrils.
options.B: As I pull gently at its crisp brown shell, the aroma of its gooey sweetness teases my nostrils.
options.C: Pulling gently at its crisp brown shell, the aroma of its gooey sweetness teasing my nostrils.
options.D: When I pull gently at its crisp brown shell, and the aroma of its gooey sweetness teasing my nostrils.

questions.questionText: How should sentence 8 be changed?

options.F: Insert a comma after grass
options.H: Change playing to to play
options.J: Change Soccer to soccer

questions.questionText: What change, if any, is needed in sentence 18?

options.A: Insert a comma after way
options.B: Change is processed to has processed
options.C: Change centers' to centers
options.D: Sentence 18 should not be changed.

questions.questionText: What change, if any, needs to be made to sentence 20?

options.F: Delete the comma
options.H: Change innocent to inocent
options.J: Make no change to sentence 20.

questions.questionText: What change, if any, should be made in sentence 1?

options.A: Change Organization to organization
options.B: Change the colon to a comma
options.C: Change species to species'
options.D: No change is needed in sentence 1.

questions.questionText: What change, if any, should be made in sentence 11?

options.F: Delete since
options.H: Change to trying to to try
options.J: No change is needed in this sentence.

questions.questionText: What change should be made in sentence 14?

options.A: Change Doing to When we do
options.B: Delete the comma after though
options.C: Change preferances to preferences
options.D: Change simply to simple

questions.questionText: What change, if any, should be made in sentence 18?

options.F: Change whose to who's
options.H: Delete the comma after try
options.J: No change is needed in sentence 18.

questions.questionText: In which lines does the poet use personification to create a somber mood?

options.A: Lines 3 through 5
options.B: Lines 9 and 10
options.C: Lines 17 through 19
options.D: Lines 28 and 29

questions.questionText: Lines 20 and 21 suggest that the speaker...

options.F: wants to be honest about how little he understands the creative impulse
options.G: does not want to mislead his daughter into believing that she has special talent
options.H: is now willing to risk hurting his daughter's self-esteem by telling her the truth about her work
options.J: wants to admit his confusion about the sometimes-stifling life choices that creative people make

questions.questionText: Read lines 26 and 27 from the poem. 'when the sky is a surreal sea / in which you drown.' This image can best be interpreted as meaning that...

options.A: a child sees the sky as a magical ocean full of mysterious creatures
options.B: the speaker hopes to save his daughter from a terrible future
options.C: artists experience a sea of wild and unpredictable emotions
options.D: there is a danger that artists may get lost in their own creations

questions.questionText: The final line of the poem suggests that...

options.F: the daughter will develop an interest in more practical pursuits as she matures
options.G: the speaker expects his daughter's art to transform as she grows older
options.H: the daughter's paintings will become more whimsical as she develops her technical skills
options.J: the speaker believes that his daughter will one day be a successful professional artist

questions.questionText: Which sentence describes a shift in the poem's focus?

options.A: In stanza 1, the speaker focuses on his daughter's creative struggles, while in stanza 2, he imagines her eventual success as an artist.
options.B: In stanza 1, the speaker focuses on his daughter's paintings, while in stanza 2, he describes his own artwork.
options.C: In stanza 1, the speaker focuses on his daughter's art as an expression of childhood, while in stanza 2, he considers her future as a mature artist.
options.D: In stanza 1, the speaker focuses on his daughter's early artistic success, while in stanza 2, he questions whether she should pursue a career as a painter.

questions.questionText: Read paragraph 15. 'His old scaly hand crawls over to touch my knee. His fingers are white, the nails cracking and dull, like old silver.' In this paragraph, the author uses imagery to...

options.F: show the son's fear of being touched by his father
options.G: imply that the father may not really be dying after all
options.H: emphasize how aged and decrepit the father appears to his son
options.J: suggest that the son has little respect for his father

questions.questionText: What does paragraph 16 reveal about the son?

options.A: He blames himself for his father's long absences.
options.B: He thinks his father never gave them the opportunity to be close.
options.C: He is too willing to forgive his father for lying.
options.D: He is unwilling to share what he knows with his father.

questions.questionText: Which line of dialogue provides the best evidence that the father is questioning his priorities?

options.F: 'Now all that seems so unimportant, you know?'
options.G: 'Remembering a man's stories makes him immortal, did you know that?'
options.H: 'I had dinner with a prime minister once, William.'
options.J: 'I wasn't going to tell you about the two-headed lady, Mr. Smarty-pants,' he says.

questions.questionText: In paragraphs 3 through 5, the phrases 'Let me guess' and 'no doubt' give the son's dialogue a tone that is...

options.A: naive
options.B: hypercritical
options.C: indignant
options.D: sarcastic

questions.questionText: Paragraph 17 suggests that the son is motivated to listen to his father because...

options.F: he values his father's advice
options.G: he regrets not paying attention to his father in the past
options.H: he believes his father is dying
options.J: he believes his father will tell him a secret

questions.questionText: Which sentence best describes the father's moral dilemma?

options.A: He must choose between impressing his son with outlandish stories and admitting that he is a financial failure.
options.B: He must resolve feelings about his failure to persuade his son to follow in his footsteps.
options.C: He must decide whether to continue to pursue his dreams or devote himself to helping his son.
options.D: He must reconcile his lifelong desire to be important with the knowledge that he neglected his family.

questions.questionText: Paragraph 20 reveals that the father views his childhood home of Ashland as...

options.F: a place of tremendous comfort
options.H: the best place to raise a family
options.J: a place of haunting memories

questions.questionText: The story explores the theme of a son...

options.A: disappointing his father
options.B: imitating his father
options.C: trying to impress his father
options.D: making peace with his father

questions.questionText: Read these quotations... These quotations provide evidence that both the speaker in 'To a Daughter with Artistic Talent' and the narrator in the excerpt from Big Fish feel...

options.F: as though they must prove something
options.H: compelled to admit their mistakes
options.J: challenged to explain something difficult

questions.questionText: What is a difference in how the two selections portray fathers?

options.A: While the father in 'To a Daughter with Artistic Talent' is optimistic, the father in the excerpt from Big Fish is cynical.
options.B: While the father in 'To a Daughter with Artistic Talent' seems caring, the father in the excerpt from Big Fish seems self-centered.
options.C: While the father in 'To a Daughter with Artistic Talent' is open-minded, the father in the excerpt from Big Fish is judgmental.
options.D: While the father in 'To a Daughter with Artistic Talent' seems defensive, the father in the excerpt from Big Fish seems relaxed.

questions.questionText: Both the daughter's paintings in 'To a Daughter with Artistic Talent' and the father's stories in the excerpt from Big Fish...

options.F: depict a world that seems more fanciful than realistic
options.G: contain imagery drawn from well-known fairy tales
options.H: are difficult for others to understand
options.J: portray heroic characters

questions.questionText: Read these quotations. Both quotations use imagery that conveys a sense of...

options.A: inner turmoil
options.B: stubbornness
options.C: guilt
options.D: exaggerated self-confidence

questions.questionText: Which sentence best states a difference between the attitude of the speaker in the poem and the attitude of the narrator in the story?

options.F: The speaker in the poem worries that his daughter gets carried away by her imagination, while the narrator in the story admires the way his father uses his imagination.
options.G: The speaker in the poem believes that his daughter paints to express her true feelings, while the narrator in the story believes that his father tells stories to escape reality.
options.H: The speaker in the poem thinks his daughter paints to bring them closer together, while the narrator in the story thinks his father tells stories to distance himself from others.
options.J: The speaker in the poem believes that painting is good for his daughter's health, while the narrator in the story worries that his father's stories are a symptom of illness.

questions.questionText: What is the author's purpose for writing this article?

options.A: To encourage people to visit national parks
options.B: To advocate for coexistence of humans and wildlife in urban areas
options.C: To explain methods for tracking a cougar through Griffith Park
options.D: To persuade people to convert urban cities back to natural spaces

questions.questionText: Which words from paragraph 7 best help the reader understand the meaning of the word resiliency?

options.F: relish my experiences
options.H: adapt to life
options.J: urban interface

questions.questionText: Why does the author use rhetorical questions in paragraph 6?

options.A: To argue that human-built environments are not suitable for wildlife
options.B: To illustrate a shift in her perspective regarding wildlife habitats
options.C: To explain that mountain lions are vastly different from other types of wildlife
options.D: To prove that she has experience on the subject of mountain lions

questions.questionText: In paragraph 12, why does the author refer to milkweed plants as 'gas stations' for monarch butterflies?

options.F: Milkweed plants are enjoyed by several species of butterflies.
options.G: Milkweed plants are becoming more available in cities.
options.H: Milkweed plants can be grown in any environment.
options.J: Milkweed plants are essential for the migration of monarch butterflies.

questions.questionText: In paragraph 5, the author conveys a tone of...

options.A: relief
options.B: surprise
options.C: humiliation
options.D: pride

questions.questionText: What is one conclusion the author makes about wildlife?

options.F: Certain urban spaces should be abandoned by people because wildlife need them more.
options.G: Larger species of wildlife are not as strong as smaller species of wildlife.
options.H: Humans need to change their understanding of wildlife preservation.
options.J: More national parks should be formed to help wildlife.

questions.questionText: Read this quotation from paragraph 9... Why does the author include this idea?

options.A: To emphasize that wildlife living in urban areas is more common than people think
options.B: To compare the wildlife found in different regions of California
options.C: To describe Mark Zuckerberg's disapproval of the foxes living on the Facebook campus
options.D: To question whether the foxes are safe living in Menlo Park

questions.questionText: In paragraph 14, what does biodiversity mean?

options.F: Decisions about nature made by people
options.H: Multiple species of plants and animals
options.J: Animals living in populated urban areas

questions.questionText: Why does the author use this comparison: 'it's like going on a roller coaster for the brain.'?

options.A: To illustrate the level of excitement a movie can provide
options.B: To explain the filmmaking techniques used by movie directors
options.C: To show how movies help people cope with real-world worries
options.D: To describe the mental processes involved with making a movie

questions.questionText: Which word from paragraph 3 means 'powerful' or 'effective'?

options.F: potent
options.H: attentional
options.J: literally

questions.questionText: What is the primary purpose of the boxed information at the end of the article?

options.A: To persuade readers to watch movies in an actual theater rather than at home
options.B: To explain why movies watched at home are less enjoyable
options.C: To give advice for ways to enhance the home movie-watching experience
options.D: To demonstrate why the convenience of watching movies at home is appealing

questions.questionText: In paragraph 1 of the article, what type of evidence does the author present?

options.F: Factual data
options.H: Persuasive argument
options.J: Anecdotal details

questions.questionText: Which statement best expresses the main idea of paragraph 5?

options.A: Movies can cause people to become emotional.
options.B: The way people relate to a movie depends on how realistic it is.
options.C: Movies can make people ignore the difference between reality and fiction.
options.D: People lose awareness of their surroundings in a movie theater.

questions.questionText: According to paragraph 6, what does the limbic system control?

options.F: Emotions
options.H: Comprehension
options.J: Spacial awareness

questions.questionText: Why does the author include paragraph 7?

options.A: To contrast the enjoyment received from older and newer movies
options.B: To express concern regarding the ways people often watch movies today
options.C: To suggest that newer movies lack emotional appeal for viewers
options.D: To explain why theater attendance has declined in recent years

questions.questionText: Which of these best describes the author's purpose for writing this article?

options.F: To inform people about what makes a movie-watching experience enjoyable
options.G: To analyze the techniques moviemakers use to create popular movies
options.H: To compare the experiences of watching a movie at home and in a theater
options.J: To persuade people to avoid watching movies on smart phones
